Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
Linking measurements of soil-derived volatile organic compounds to atmospheric emissions models

Forests represent the primary source of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) globally, and VOCs significantly impact ecological and atmospheric processes, including the production of ozone. Most of what is known about VOC production in forests comes from studies of live foliage. However, recent work indicates that roots and soil microbes can be considerable sources of VOCs, with implications for models of atmospheric chemistry and ecosystem carbon budgets. In this project, soil and canopy VOC fluxes will be quantified in situ in forests dominated by different tree species. The physiological mechanisms and primary biogeochemical drivers responsible for VOC emissions from roots and soil microbes will be determined, leading to the development of mechanistic emission models that predict VOC effects on atmospheric composition and air quality. The results from this project will contribute a comprehensive mechanistic understanding of biological and physical controls over VOC emissions from the molecular-to-ecosystem-to-atmospheric scales. Results will be used to improve models of global VOC emissions and atmospheric chemistry.

Training objectives include the integration of molecular, biogeochemical, and mathematical modeling techniques to explore a pressing ecological issue with implications for local and global air quality. Broader impacts include unique collaborative opportunities for research across diverse disciplines and between international institutions. Outreach activities include training and mentoring a number of underrepresented undergraduates through the Science, Technology, and Research Scholars (STARS) program, developing a research-related curriculum for a free science workshop series, and providing annual reports to both land managers and the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dr. Amy Trowbridge successfully met the project objectives set forth in her postdoctoral work supported by the NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology Program. During the funding period, she spent six months at the prestigious Helmholtz Zentrum in Munich, Germany working with the Environmental Simulations Unit (EUS) headed by Prof. Dr. Joerg-Peter Schinitzler. The advanced analytical tools and sophisticated phytotron facility offered Dr. Trowbridge training in new techniques to investigate carbon investment in above and belowground plant volatile compounds in response to environmental conditions. The remainder of her time was spent working with Dr. Richard Phillips in the Biology Department and Dr. Philip Stevens in the Chemistry Department at Indiana University. There she learned about different methods to assess soil and root processes, a novel instrument to measure hydroxyl radical reactivity, and leveraged the data and infrastructure at the Ameriflux Tower at Morgan Monroe State Forest to examine seasonal controls over soil and litter volatile compounds and their potential impact on regional air quality.

 The ultimate goal of this work was to quantify soil and canopy volatile compound fluxes as a function of species and associated mycorrhizal associations in an intact forest, but also to describe the physical and biological factors that control these emissions so to improve existing models. To this end, a multidisciplinary approach was necessary, and through her mentorship, Dr. Trowbridge was able to integrate molecular, biogeochemical, and atmospheric sampling techniques and approaches and begin to fill a critical gap in our understanding of how soil and root processes may influence whole-ecosystem volatile fluxes and thereby regional air chemistry. Her experiences allowed her to develop a series of novel sampling protocols and couple a variety of advanced analytical techniques, which have led to a number of key findings relevant across disciplines. Measurements from soil collars installed across a species/mycorrhizal gradient in the field suggest that litter is the primary source of belowground volatile emissions, but the strength of this source is significantly affected not only by leaf litter type, but the strength of the soil as a sink, which is likely influenced by associated microbial communities. This source-sink dynamic is affected by seasonality and phenology. Thus, the importance of these emissions to total ecosystem volatile compound fluxes varies substantially across the growing season. In addition to environmental variables, results from Dr. Trowbridge’s laboratory work performed in Germany suggest that biotic stresses such as herbivore feeding can also alter the magnitude of belowground volatile emissions as well as carbon allocation towards these volatiles. Furthermore, her work shows that even though enzyme activity responsible for root volatile synthesis is up-regulated following herbivory, the sink strength of the soil can significantly impact what is measured at the soil/atmosphere interface and thereby what enters the atmosphere. This is important as scientists may be underestimating the magnitude of belowground volatile emissions and their influence on belowground interactions due to limitations associated with current sampling techniques. These key findings will be integrated with results from a hydroxyl radical reactivity campaign and a litter removal experiment to offer a comprehensive mechanistic understanding of the sources and controls over soil volatile emissions and improve global emission models.

 This project has given Dr. Trowbridge a unique opportunity to mentor a number of undergraduate and graduate students as well as two student research assistants/technicians.
